turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: What!?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I said, yeah, about once a week!

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Oh!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Sorry. I'm better with men.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Maybe we should try a different kind of dancing.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: You mean like disco dancing or doing the funky chicke...Oh. I get it.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Mordechai?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Yes Esther.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: I want you to talk dirty to me.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Oh. Okay.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I want for our children to go to private schools and take music lessons. Little Abraham will go to Stanford for college, Batya will go Ivy League, maybe Vassar.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Keep going.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Afterwards they'll make the decision as to whether or not they'd like to continue their religious studies in Israel. Because, hey, after all we'll have practiced the highly effective assertive democratic style of child rearing, sprinkled with a healthy dose of liberalism.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Also, on a daily basis, I want you to tell me what to do, where to do it, and how I should live my life.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Kiss me you Semitic stud!

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Your mother was right. You do work too hard.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Oh, she said that, did she? What else did Mommy Dearest have to say?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: When did you guys have this conversation? When I was in the bathroom? What else did she have to say?

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Relax Morty, I think your mom is wonderful. She cares so much about you. Get this, while you were gone she said she'd help me get you to work with the JDL if I'd come eat by you once in awhile. Like I needed any incentive to be with you. She's so...

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Oh my god. She's become my pimp. And she's whoring her bitch-son out to the highest bidder.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: No. It's not like that. You're being completely neurotic. I was just playing along...

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: We do!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I'm sorry Esther, I just don't think we can see each other romantically anymore.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Mordechai, I love you. I couldn't let you do this alone.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I love you too. I'm sorry about freaking out yesterday. I was wrong.

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: I forgive you.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Esther!

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Mordechai!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Esther!

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: Mordechai!

turns.speaker: ESTHER
turns.text: You two know each other?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: We go to the same temple.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Shabat Shalom mama. I brought some Manischewitz. The black label.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: I can see. And you also brought a nice girl to come eat by us.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Mordechai. Do you love your mother?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Mom, stop with this already. Of course I love you. You're my mother.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Mom, I have a real job. I do good things for this community. I help people.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: When I play bridge with all the girls, everyone has what to talk about with their sons. They show pictures. Their sons are lawyers and doctors and Rabbis. Why can't I show a picture?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: So don't show a picture.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: You know my friend Maureen? Her son, the investment banker? He paid for her entire retirement in Boca Raton. What a mench he is. Instead of schleping to save Hanukkah, god forbid you should go back to business school and get an MBA. Maybe then you could send me to Boca, too.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: I don't want to argue with you. Let's just eat in peace.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: No. No. We're gonna argue. And you know what mom? I'm going to save Hanukkah just to spite you. And when my face is all over the television. When your friends are opening their Hanukkah gifts next year, don't mention it to them, okay? I wouldn't want you to have to show my picture.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Do what you must.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Let's let your tuchus breathe.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Mom, why don't you put that cat out of its misery?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: ...and the opportunity to help my brothers and sisters in the Jewish community.

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Well I'm just glad you're safe Bubba Shaina, and eating by your mother for Shabos.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: ...and their children will all be able to eat latkes and spin dreidels, and light the menorah with the knowl...

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: ...So you saved Hanukkah Mr. Big Shot. I mean, let's be honest Mordechai, it isn't even one of the high holidays.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Well I have news for you mom. It is good enough...I'm good enough and I won't leave here until I hear you tell me...

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Mazel Tov!

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: Hello Mazel Tov! A boojee boojee boojee boo...

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: ...I'm not finished yet, mom.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Mom! We're eating!

turns.speaker: MRS. CARVER
turns.text: What a good poop you made in your diaper Mazel Tov! That's right! Mommy loves you! Such a good boy you are!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Happy Hanukkah Tikva.

turns.speaker: TIKVA
turns.text: Happy Hanukkah Morty.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Okay, what's the information?

turns.speaker: TIKVA
turns.text: She said to remind you that you're having Shabat dinner by her tomorrow and also to remind you to bring the Manischewitz.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Anything else?

turns.speaker: TIKVA
turns.text: Yeah, I'm going to be out of the office from 1:30 to 3:00 on Sunday. I have a terrible yeast infection and I need to see my gynecologist.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: But we're not open on Sundays.

turns.speaker: TIKVA
turns.text: I understand that. I just thought that you might want to know.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I'll be in my office.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: So Morde-chai, tell me, what brings your bad self down to the KLF?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I'm back on the job for the JDL. You hear about that crazy white boy who took over as Santa?

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Oh, most definitely. Got the brothers here in full alert mode.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Actually, I...I don't. What does that mean?

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Oh. It means that Santa's gonna fuck Hanukkah's shit up.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Not if I can help it. You got any information for me?

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: You watch your back Hammer. Hanukkah might just be his first move. For all we know Kwanzaa could be next. There's a lot of brothers counting on you. If you fail...

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Okay, look. I'm going to work really, really hard on this one. But, please stop with the pressure. I'm already tense as it is.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: It's cool. It's cool. Aveenooh Shalom Alechem, brother.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: What's wrong with him?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: He's still working out some identity issues.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: It's gonna be tough, but the back entrance looks like our best bet.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: I wanted to ask you, how were you able to pinpoint the exact location of Santa's workshop? We've been trying to gain that piece of surveillance for years.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Cool. What's it do?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Now this might get a bit technical, but try and stay with me. Using a highly sophisticated connection of other computators, called the Internet, I can access surveillance maps, villian biographical information, and even sports scores with a few simple keystrokes of this electronic typewriter.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Man, that's far out! Hey, the Jets won!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: But wait, there's more. With a few swift clicks of this hand-computer interface, commonly referred to as a mouse, I can download illicit pornographic material and even send it along to a friend via a cyber postal route known as e-mail.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Porno? You're tellin' me that you can get porno on that thing?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Oh yeah. Take a look.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Just praying to god that we don't kill ourselves going over this wall.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Wait! Before we enter, you need to know that my research has determined that Santa's compound is wired with the XP 2000 stereo type alarm system.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: A stereo type alarm system?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Take a look.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: How do we bypass it?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: The alarm will trigger if the system detects any Non-W.A.S.P. tendencies inside the building. For example, if you were to dribble a basketball, or eat watermelon, or use the word dawg...that is, spelled with an aw as opposed to the letter o...within the confines of this workshop, the alarm would sound.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Listen cat, I'll have you know that I hate the taste of watermelon and am a terrible basketball player.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Well that's good news for us. It means the system is outdated. This should be easy. C'mon.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Offscreen gunfire. That Jewish Atomic Clock stuff ate up a lot of our budget.

turns.speaker: MOHAMMED
turns.text: Hammer, you alright?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Everything's kosher. Watch him for me.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Sorry folks, I don't do couples.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: If you keep your mouth shut and come with me, you won't get hurt.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Excuse me? Do I know you, friend? Take a look around you. Do you even know who I am?

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Let me guess, you're the goy who stole Hanukkah.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: The Hebrew Hammer! You're alive.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: What's your shpiel, Santa?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Whoa, whoa there. C'mon Mordechai, is this any way to treat an old family friend? Let's cut out all the unpleasantness. I admit, I went way overboard with the whole Hanukkah thing. Let me make it up to you. How about a peace offering?  Girls.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: I'm just calming the kiddies.  There's no need to worry about Santa. He's just having a peaceful, adult conversation with his nice Jewish friend, The Hebrew Hammer.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Hey everybody. How's it hangin'?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: In fact, he's just informed me that he personally plans on cancelling Christmas this year.

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: Where's my girlfriend Santa?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: I don't have to tell you anything Hammer! You're gonna have to kill me before I tell you!

turns.speaker: HAMMER
turns.text: I shlepped all the way to the North Pole for this? I come to fight you, and you don't even put out anything to nosh on? What kind of arch nemesis are you?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Hah! Jewish guilt. Well, it won't work on me Hammer. I'm too strong for it.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: So, what's our first plan of attack Santa?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: While I was in Taiwan negotiating the solution to our labor problems, I came across a factory that illegally manufactures the most addictive, Jewish pride weakening substance on the planet. I bought the entire plant.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: What should I charge?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Oh, that's the beauty of it. These are free samples.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: So what's in the boxes? Heroin? Cocaine?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Worse.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Bootleg copies of the Frank Capra classic, 'It's A Wonderful Life.'

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: That's some cold shit.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: So, how was I?

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: It was good. Very chilling, but you still got all the points across that we talked about.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: I wasn't too over the top?

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: No, it was the perfect level.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Thanks. Oh, did I tell you. I picked up that new KC and the Sunshine Band record that you recommended. You were right, it is good.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: You okay?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: No. I'm airsick you asshole! Where the hell did these reindeer learn to fly?

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: I don't know. Why don't you ask them sir.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Get off of me you cripple!

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: What are we gonna do? He's got us on the ropes.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: What's going on? Why'd he stop?

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: Maybe he ran out of ammo.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Take a look.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: Well, he's kinda just resting in the corner with his girlfriend.

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: Resting?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: What day is it?

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: It's Friday.

turns.speaker: TINY TIM
turns.text: You want me to be nice to him for no apparent reason whatsoever, buy him clothing he'll never wear, and for just one day of the year pretend to forgive him for all the horrible things he did to me as a young boy when my mommy wasn't looking?

turns.speaker: SANTA
turns.text: No dipshit, I want you to kill him.

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Is someone with you -- can I get you a drink?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: My soninlaw. What do you think of him?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: That depends. How much money has he?

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: When you marry champagne, Clo-Clo, you can't trade it in for beer. You're stuck with it.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: I can't understand that fancy talk.  You mean I'm a gold-digger? Sure, I'm a gold-digger -- why not?

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Why not -- if you like it - if that's what you really want.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Maybe I should just forget all about money - - forget about mamma and the kids and the rent, huh - marry some poor dope like -- oh, like Carlos Dominguez - - and get fat and -

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Who's Carlos Dom-what's-his-name?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Nobody. A boy who works in a grocery.

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Good looking?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Mmmyes.

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Nice fellow?

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Is he in love with you?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: I don't know -

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Why do you ask so many questions? What difference does it make how Carlos and I feel? Feeling does not buy clothes and houses!

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: Drink your beer and don't get so excited.

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: This is for "mama and the kids."

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: BRUNTON
turns.text: You get your money from your husband.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Here is something that should interest Charlie - a stone leopard head made by his ancestors some six hundred years ago. They used it in ceremonies. The jaguar -- in fact all the cat family -- were considered the personification of force and violence in their religious rites.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: It don't look like a leopard to me.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Well, Charlie, just why do you think your cat didn't kill the Contreras girl?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You know -- not scared enough. Nothing to scare it.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: If a leopard didn't do it, who did?

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Oh, I'm only exploring your theory. Let's take a step further. You drink, don't you, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I drink.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: And when you drink, you get drunk.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Then what do you do?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I sleep it off.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: But between the time you leave the cant ma and fall into bed in that old truck of yours, what happens, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I don't know.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: That's just it, Charlie. That's what I'm driving at. You could do anything in that time.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Now I know I didn't hurt nobody when I was drunk - -

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Of course, not, Charlie. I never thought you did.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And my leopard - - maybe he hurt the first girl -- but no more.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Can't make a buck without my leopard. I tell you, Mr. Manning, you gotta find that cat for me -- or pay up.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look, Charlie, just be patient. I'll fix everything. You don't want that cat, anyway. It killed two people.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No, sir. That girl in the cemetery? My cat didn't kill that girl. I told you cats don't go around looking for trouble. If that cat's alive, it's out in the country hiding under a bush, starving to death.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You really think so, Charlie?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: That cat ain't mean. I feed him out of my own hand for six years. Why don't he kill me? At night in the truck, I let him out of the cage. When I am falling asleep I hear him walking back and forth. I go to sleep. He don't hurt me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: They all say the cat killed this second girl.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: They don't say it to me.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: I'd like one of them to say it to you, Charlie. I'd like to have you hear his side of it his reasons. Want to hear them?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Let's get in your truck.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Where's that man?

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Up at the museum.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Sure, I like my leopards

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: But he admitted quick enough that it killed the first girl.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Sure!

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: No. I'm serious about this.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Charlie wasn't drunk last night.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Yes, I was drunk, Mr. Manning.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I'm sick.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Here have a cigarette. He was only kidding.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No, he wasn't kidding. I'm sick. Claw women? Hurt little girls? No!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I don't know. I want to see Robles.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What do you want to see him for?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I want him to lock me up.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Look, Charlie, you didn't do it, and you know you didn't.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I don't know. I want him to lock me up.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Two hundred and fifty dollars you owe met

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: You found the leopard!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: What's left of him.

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: Where? Where did you find it?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: North -- in an arroyo, Shot through the head - maybe week ago. No good, skin, everything gone 

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: What arroyo - how did you get to it 

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: And here is Three Tree Mesa -- and here I go out of the big arroyo --

turns.speaker: JERRY
turns.text: That's the place: I remember - My feet were so darn sore, I couldn't make it -- and Galbraith went on up to the head of the canyon by himself --

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: It's a blackcard and bad card, but not the card of the cat - not the card of fourfooted things.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: I saw Teresa. Maybe I was the last to see her except perhaps her Mamacita and her little brother. I was going past --

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: ) They buried Teresa today and they were hunting the leopard again -- out in the country this time. But they didn't get him.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: They're fools. Why don't they let Charlie How-Come hunt it alone. He's an Indian.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: All men are fools. They like to make a big show - shout and hunt --

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: What did they say before the bad card came up?

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: You'll meet a rich man and he will give, you money.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: You and your cards. Meet a rich man! I look for them with money. What rich man hasn't money. And for what was I born if it wasn't for money? You're not telling me anything.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Watch and see, A day or a week - but certainly this month -- you will have money from a man and then-

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Well -- did he give you a lot of money?

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: The elderly man I told you about.

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Cut.

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: What are you doing that for?

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Something black - something on its way to you 

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Go on -

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Don't look at it!

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: Let me see it 

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: The death card - -

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Maybe not - cards mean different things different times --

turns.speaker: CLO-CLO
turns.text: See you tomorrow -

turns.speaker: MARIA
turns.text: Tomorrow -

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: He will be waiting...

turns.speaker: ROSITA
turns.text: You must say that you went to take some of the roses to your father's grave...

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: At four. He will be there at four.

turns.speaker: ROSITA
turns.text: Pedro is waiting for me, too.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: Rosita  I have wondered -

turns.speaker: ROSITA
turns.text: What, senorita?

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: When you are going to see Pedro, does your heart beat until you tremble?

turns.speaker: ROSITA
turns.text: Love is different for different people.

turns.speaker: CONSUELO
turns.text: I suppose so. I suppose it will be different for us, too  when everyone knows. Then we will be just like other people.  But these last weeks will always be our secret  a lovely secret to remember all our lives.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: It may sound like music to her -- I can do better with my teeth in a cold Shower.  Click  click  click.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: She's a local. When the dudes come out to New Mexico, they went to wallow in Latin glamour. This is a bad town for blondes.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Yes. So I've noticed. Jerry's noticed - He'll come up with something.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: You think be's pretty nice, don't you?

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Why not? He's a good press agent and a good friend. Besides, we've shared a lot of headaches 

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: You're lucky. I wish he'd front page for me.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Maybe. For three years I've sung in rats' nests, while Jerry pounded his feet off and his brains out -- trying to get me a real chance. We're due for a little luck!

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: I mean you being a star and me being just a cigarette girl.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I know. I know. You've got the talent. I got the breaks.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: And if you've got cold feet honey, Ill take over for you. That red dress of yours fits just perfect on me.

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: I bet you try on my coffin some day -- I hope it "fits just perfect."

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: Oh, dear -- I don't know what I'm going to do without you - honestly, I don't 

turns.speaker: KIKI
turns.text: Hey  I'm over here.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: I'll miss you too, honey --

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: Oh, Mr. Galbraith! I'm so glad you're here.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Good evening.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: You know all about these things - - and I've lived here all my life - and I still don't know what the Procession means.

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: It's to remind people of the great tragedy that took place here so that they won't ever forget that a peaceful village of Indians was wiped out by the Conquistadores, back in the 17th Century... A band of monks buried the dead and prayed for them and did penance for their deaths  that's what this procession is supposed to be.

turns.speaker: ELOISE
turns.text: Oh, that's so interesting!

turns.speaker: GALBRAITH
turns.text: Well, now that you've had your history lesson, I think I'll get on to the museum.
